block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Theater

BANANAS COMEDY CLUB Quentin Heggs with Robert Rothstein and Darryl Shippley. Friday at 9:30 p.m.; Saturday at 8:30 p.m. and 10:45 p.m. Otto and George. Saturday at 10:45 p.m. Tickets: $10 on Friday; $12 on Saturday. Holiday Inn, 283 Route 17 South, Hasbrouck Heights. (201) 727-1090.

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''Three Murders and It's Only Monday,'' murder mystery comedy spoof. Through next Sunday. Friday at 8:30 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m.; today and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $17 for Friday and Saturday; $16 for Sundays; $15 for students and older people on Friday and Saturday; $10 for students and older people on Sundays. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Theater

BANANAS COMEDY CLUB Quentin Heggs with Robert Rothstein and Darryl Shippley. Friday at 9:30 p.m.; Saturday at 8:30 p.m. and 10:45 p.m. Otto and George. Saturday at 10:45 p.m. Tickets: $10 on Friday; $12 on Saturday. Holiday Inn, 283 Route 17 South, Hasbrouck Heights. (201) 727-1090.

EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''Three Murders and It's Only Monday,'' murder mystery comedy spoof. Through next Sunday. Friday at 8:30 p.m.; Saturday at 8 p.m.; today and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $17 for Friday and Saturday; $16 for Sundays; $15 for students and older people on Friday and Saturday; $10 for students and older people on Sundays. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.
HUDSON SHAKESPEARE COMPANY ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' Tomorrow at 7 p.m. Free. Pier A Park, River Road and First Street, Hoboken. (201) 420-2207.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Razzmatazz,'' musical celebrating popular songs of the 20th century. Through Sept. 9 Monday through Saturday luncheon matinees beginning at 11 a.m.; Saturdays at 6:30 p.m.; Sundays at 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $39.50 to $51 (includes show and lunch/dinner). Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.

LUMIA THEATER ''The Girl With the High Rouge,'' Vincent Sessa's surreal comic-drama, performed by the New Jersey Repertory Company. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
LUMIA THEATER -- STAGE II ''About Anne,'' featuring Salome Jens as Anne Sexton, poet. Thursday through Saturday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.

MURDER TO GO THEATER ''Killing Mr. Withers.'' Ongoing. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $45 on Fridays; $48 on Saturdays, includes four-course dinner. Il Giardino, Cedar Knolls. (973) 301-0562.
NEW JERSEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL ''Rhinoceros.'' Performances are Tuesday through Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $21 to $38. F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 408-5600.

OPEN AIR THEATER ''Carnival!'' sponsored by the Princeton Opera Association. Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m. Free Parking. Tickets: $7.50 to $9; half price for children. Washington Crossing State Park, Titusville. (609) 737-1826.

PLAYS IN THE PARK ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' Wednesday through Aug. 31. Performances every night at 8:30 p.m. except Sundays. Tickets: $3; free for children 12 and under. Stephen J. Capestro Theater, Roosevelt Park, off of Route 1 South, Edison. (732) 548-2884.

RITZ THEATER ''Broadway Overtures,'' the third presentation in the Ritz 2000 Concert Series. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $12.50. ''Geist, Contemporary Vaudevillianism!'' Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $16 (Friday and Saturday); $12.50 (Sunday). 915 White Horse Pike, Oaklyn. (609) 858-5230.
Music
BARRON ARTS CENTER VooDudes Lawn Concert. Friday at 8 p.m. Free. 582 Rahway Avenue, Woodbridge. (732) 634-0413.

CHALFONTE HOTEL ''Concerts by Candlelight'' featuring Cantilena. Tuesday at 8:30 p.m. in the Henry Sawyer Room. Tickets: $7, or free with dinner. ''For Me. . .Formidable!'' cabaret of French songs, featuring Jilline Ringle. Wednesday through Sept. 17. Performances are at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and older people; $8 for children under 12. 301 Howard Street, Cape May. (609) 884-8409.
THE CORNERSTONE Sarah Partridge Trio. Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Kenny Davern Quartet. Friday at 9 p.m. Mike LeDonne Quartet. Saturday at 9 p.m. 25 New Street, Metuchen. (732) 549-5306.
DARRESS THEATER Contemporary Chamber Music concert featuring compositions by Robert W. Butts and Nicholas Harris. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $5. Main Street, Boonton. (973) 334-9292.
FAIR LAWN SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL Howard Tavin and Annette Sanders. Today at 8:30 p.m. Free. Memorial Park, Berdan Avenue, Fair Lawn. (201) 796-6746.
FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY OF ELIZABETH Dr. Richard Kogan, pianist. Saturday at 2:15 p.m. 11 South Broad Street, Elizabeth. (908) 354-6060.
FREEHOLD CENTER PARTNERSHIP The Nerds. Thursday, 7:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Free. Freehold Hall of Records. (732) 462-3584.

THE MANOR Jeff Harnar and Shauna Hicks in ''Shauna and Jeff Sing Mickey and Judy.'' Thursday at 9 p.m. (dinner seatings at 6 p.m., 6:15 p.m. and 6:30 p.m.). Cost: $69 for dinner and show (plus tax and tip). 111 Prospect Avenue, West Orange. (973) 731-2369.

MAXWELL'S David Allen's University of Errors and Shell. Today at 10 p.m. Tickets: $10. The Posies and Shannon Wright. Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $8. The Amazing Crowns and the Heartdrops. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $7. Shades Apart and the Pilfers. Saturday at 9:30 p.m. Tickets: $7. 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken. (201) 653-1703.

MIDDLESEX COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION The Paul Dehnz Band. Today, 3 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Johnson Park, River Road, Piscataway. Nick Novicky and the Verstyles Polka Band. Today, 6 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. Warren Park, Florida Grove Road, Woodbridge. Bob Beck and the Bottom of the Ninth. Today, 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Spring Lake Park, Maple Avenue, South Plainfield. Free. (732) 745-3900.

MINSTREL COFFEEHOUSE Mad Pudding (Candadian Celtic funk band) and Bob Norman. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $5. Morris County Park Commission's Cultural Center, 300 Mendham Road, Morristown. (973) 335-9489.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER ''Absolut Sounds of the City 2000,'' outdoor music series. Thursday evenings, 5 to 10 o'clock, through Aug. 31. New Jersey Capoeira Institute (Brazilian martial arts and percussion); Point 3 Hope (hard Latin rock); Bradford Hayes Quartet (jazz); and Ray Rodriguez and the Latin Jazz Project. Free. Theater Square. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
NORTH WILDWOOD SUMMER SERIES Good Old Vaudeville Days. Thursday at 8 p.m. The Platters. Saturday at 8 p.m. Free. North Wildwood's amphitheater, Ocean and Second Avenues. Free. (609) 889-2241.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART ''Sunset at the Noyes,'' with Minas, Philadelphia's premier Brazilian band featuring Patricia King and Orlando Haddad. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848, ext. 12.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Sept. 9. Great Auditorium Organ Recital featuring Gordon Tuck, organist, and David Peckham, guest organist. Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Free. ''Erin Forever!'' an evening of traditional Irish music and dancing featuring the Irish Rovers, Cherish the Ladies and the Donny Golden Champion Dancers. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 (reserved); $20 (general admission). The Great Auditorium, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.

PNC BANK ARTS CENTER Counting Crows and Live. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $28 to $48. Nickelodeon's All That Music and More Festival. Saturday at 5 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $35. Luther Vandross and Boyz II Men. Next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20.25 to $60.25. Exit 116, off the Garden State Parkway, Holmdel. (201) 507-8900.
PRINCETON UNIVERSITY CHAPEL Daniel K. Kehoe, Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut. Free. Today at 1 p.m. Free. William Street and Washington Road, Princeton. (609) 258-3654.
RAHWAY DIVISION OF PARKS AND RECREATION The Mayor's Concert Series featuring the David Cedeno Band. Thursday at 7 p.m. Free. West Main Street at Irving Street, Rahway. (732) 669-3600.

SHANGHAI JAZZ Warren Vache Trio. Wednesday at 7 p.m. The Kenny Barron Quartet. Thursday and Friday at 6:30 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Tickets: dinner and show, $59 (Thursday); $69 (Friday). Earl May Quartet. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. No cover. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.

SIX FLAGS GREAT ADVENTURE ''Latin Fest,'' featuring performances by George Lamond, Frankie Negron, Barrio Boyzz and more. Today, 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. Free with park admission. Northern Star Arena, exit 7A off the New Jersey Turnpike. (732) 928-2000.
SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION Lonnie Youngblood (rhythm and blues). Tonight at 7 p.m. Free. Duke Island Park bandshell, across from Visitor's Center. (908) 722-1200, ext. 351.

STANHOPE HOUSE End of Summer BBQ, featuring ulu, Juggling Suns, 2nd Left and Matte Witte's New Blood Revival. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $10.55. Project/Object. Wednesday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $12. The Party Band. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $7. Billy Hector and the Fairlanes. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $6. Roadside Louie and the Dusters. Saturday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $6. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.
TIERNEY'S TAVERN Open Swing Jazz Jam Session with the James L. Dean Quintet. Today, 8 p.m. to 11 p.m. Cover: $5. 136 Valley Road, Montclair. (973) 744-9785.
Museums and Galleries

ABC GALLERY ''The Fruits of My Labor, Oil Paintings and Pastels by Fern Blumber.'' Tomorrow through Aug. 29. Preview reception: Thursday, 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 1 to 9 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Lambertville Public Library, 6 Lilly Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-0275.

AFRICAN ART MUSEUM OF THE S.M.A. FATHERS ''Eloquent Threads: The Language of African Costumes and Textiles.'' Through Dec. 31. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 23 Bliss Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 894-8611.

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''Workers' Portraits,'' photodocumentary exhibit by Robert Gumpert. Through Dec. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.
BARRON ARTS CENTER ''New Jersey Teen Arts'' art exhibit. Through Tuesday. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. 582 Rahway Avenue, Woodbridge. (732) 634-0413.
BERLEX LABORATORIES CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS ''Beauty: Outside and Inside,'' by Bertha E. Barmakian. Through Sept. 6. By appointment. 340 Changebridge Road, Montville. (973) 276-2000.

BRION GALLERIES ''Alien Beings of Uncertain Origin,'' one-man show of monotypes by Stephen McKenzie. Through next Sunday. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB GALLERY ''Fragile Dependencies: A Close Look at Delicate Relationships in Nature.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Route 206, Lawrenceville, three miles south of Princeton. (609) 252-6275.

CAMDEN COUNTY CULTURAL AND HERITAGE COMMISSION ''Home Traditions,'' an exhibition of domestic artifacts crafted by New Jersey folk artists. Bobbie Diamond Adams exhibition of mixed media painting and prints. James Cicalese exhibition of photographs. Through Sept. 8. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. Hopkins House, 250 South Park Drive, Haddon Township. (609) 858-0040.

CERULEAN FINE ARTS GALLERY ''New Works,'' a summer membership show, with paintings in all media, sculpture and photography. Through Sept. 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 4 to 9 p.m. Headquarters Plaza Mall, Speedwell Avenue (Route 202), Morristown. (973) 267-3730.
CHAMOT GALLERY ''From Pop to the Millennium: 40 Years of Bill Barrell.'' Through Sept. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

CLEOPATRA STEPS OUT GALLERY ''Hang 10,'' fine crafts, home accessories, paintings and photography by 10 contemporary artists. Through Sept. 2. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Mondays through Wednesdays by appointment. 721 Cookman Avenue, Asbury Park. (732) 774-6306.

EXTENSION GALLERY ''Together by Chance'' two-dimensional and three-dimensional works by the school's staff and apprentices. Through Aug. 31. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. 60 Ward Avenue Extension, Mercerville. (609) 890-7777.

GALLERY ONE MAIN ''Summertime Hues,'' featuring members of the New Jersey Water color Society and members of the Garden State Watercolor Society. Through August. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Route 513, Highbridge. (908) 638-3838.

GREAT BAY GALLERY Exhibit by Peter Gehring, ''Linear Scapes -- Works on Canvas and Paper.'' Through August. Hours: Thursdays and Fridays, 1 to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. 829 Bay Avenue, Somers Point. (609) 653-4991.

GREENE & GREENE GALLERY ''Discoveries!'' Introducing 10 art jewelers to the region. Through Sept. 4. Hours: Wednesdays through Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Tuesdays, noon to 5 p.m.; and by appointment. 32 Bridge Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-7774.

GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE ''Summer 2000 Exhibition.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Tuesday and Wednesday by appointment. 18 Fairgrounds Road, Hamilton Township. (609) 586-0616.

HUNTERDON MUSEUM OF ART Lyanne Malamed, paintings and drawings. Through Sept. 10. ''Four Points of View: Artists From Lambertville.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. 7 Lower Center Street, Clinton. (908) 735-8415.

J.C.C. ON THE PALISADES ''Exploring Collage,'' exhibition by Naomi Kahan, a Ridgewood artist. Through Aug. 29. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m to 10 p.m.; Friday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. 411 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 569-7900, extension 433.

JERSEY CITY MUSEUM ''The Prints of a Sculptor,'' by Melvin Edwards. Through Oct. 7. Hours: Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesdays, 10:30 a.m.to 8 p.m. 472 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 547-4514.

LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES ''Foundation Faculty Exhibition.'' Through Sept. 6. ''2000 Craft Gallery.'' Through Oct. 15. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.

MARSHA CHILD CONTEMPORARY ''Art and the Female Form.'' Through Aug. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; other times by appointment. 220 Alexander Street, Princeton. (609) 497-7330.

MONMOUTH MUSEUM ''New Jersey's Pinelands: Water in the Balance.'' Through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4. 761 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft. (732) 747-2266.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Croquet: The Art of Play.' Through Oct. 15. Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Sept. 9 through Oct. 15, course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children. ''Will Barnet: A Timeless World.'' Through next Sunday. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''1900,'' exhibit of photos, products and objects. Through September. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.
MORRIS COUNTY PARKS Photography by Ann McGlynn. Through August. Free. Hours: daily, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center, 247 Southern Boulevard, Chatham. (973) 635-6629.

MORRIS MUSEUM New Jersey Arts Annual: ''Everything for the Home'' juried exhibition. Through Nov. 17. ''A Collector's Vision: Selections From the Collections of Edmund W. Pease and Nurak Israsena.'' Through Sept. 17. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

MUSEUM OF EARLY TRADES AND CRAFTS ''Time Made Visible: An Exhibit on Time and Timepieces.'' Through Dec. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $3.50; $2 for students, children over 5 and older people. Main Street at Green Village Road, Madison. (973) 377-2982.

MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN HUNGARIAN FOUNDATION ''Then and Now: Recent Museum Acquisitions of Art and Folk Art.'' Through Sept. 17. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. 300 Somerset Street, New Brunswick. (732) 846-5777.
NABISCO GALLERY ''Alchemy: Society of Layerists in Multi-Media.'' Through Sept. 6. Hours: daily, noon to 4 p.m. 100 DeForest Avenue, East Hanover. (973) 503-2000.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEW JERSEY STATE MUSEUM ''Building a Collection: Fine Art at the New Jersey State Museum.'' Through next Sunday. ''Leah Phyfer Sloshberg Collection of Fine Art.'' Through Sept. 3. ''The Art of Jack Delano.'' Through Sept. 4. ''Of Rock and Fire.'' On extended view. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Free. 205 West State Street, Trenton. (609) 292-6464.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Wetlands.'' Through Sept. 17. ''2000 New Jersey Fine Arts Annual: Into the Millennium.'' Through Sept. 17. ''The Luminous Image, V,'' and exhibition of illuminated photography. Through Oct. 8. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART Inspired by Nature series, featuring ''Recreating Flowers: The Glass Wonders of Paul J. Stankard.'' Through Sept. 3. ''Capturing the Jersey Shore: Works of Anthony J. Rudisill.'' Through Sept. 10. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

OCEAN COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Ocean County From the Explorers to 1950,'' featuring photographs, documents, paintings and objects illustrating the county's history. Through Oct. 31. Hours: Tuesdays and Thursdays, 1 to 3 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. 26 Hadley Avenue, Toms River. (732) 341-1880.
OLD CHURCH CULTURAL CENTER Faculty Show. Wednesday through Sept. 29. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. 561 Piermont Road, Demarest. (201) 767-7160.

PATERSON MUSEUM ''Up on Two Wheels: A Look Back at Motorcycling in North Jersey,'' show includes antique, classic, military, police, American, Japanese and European models. Through Sept. 24. ''Pair of Progenitors: The Art of Don Kommit and Joe Ruffilo.'' Through Sept. 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 12:30 to 4:30 p.m. 2 Market Street, Paterson. (973) 881-3839.

PETERS VALLEY CRAFT EDUCATION CENTER ''Art in the Open: The Peters Valley Gallery Without Walls'' exhibition featuring seven craft artists from New Jersey. Through Sept. 30. 19 Kuhn Road, Layton. (973) 948-5200.
PRINCETON UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM Photographs by Barbara Bosworth. Through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Princeton campus. (609) 258-3788.

PRINTMAKING COUNCIL OF NEW JERSEY ''26th Annual Members' Juried Exhibition: Prints, photography, digital work, juried by the artist Arie Galles.'' Through Saturday. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m. 440 River Road, North Branch. (908) 725-2110.

RIDGEWOOD ART INSTITUTE Members Summer Invitational Art Show. Through Aug. 30. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. and 8 p.m. to 10 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to noon. 12 East Glen Avenue, Ridgewood. (201) 652-9615.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEW BRUNSWICK ''Folkways and Politics: Halina Rusak -- Artist, Librarian and Scholar.'' Through Aug. 31. Hours: while school in session Mondays through Thursdays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Mabel Smith Douglass Library, Chapel Drive, Douglass College campus, New Brunswick. (732) 932-9407 extension 44.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK ''2000 Fine Arts Annual: Into the Millennium,'' featuring Sandy Skoglund's sculptures. Through Sept. 17. Prints and Drawings by Anaida Hernandez, 1989-1999. Through September. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m. to midnight; Friday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 10 p.m. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5900.

SEA BRIGHT LIBRARY Karen Cohen and Linda Levy: Joint Art Show. Through August 30. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays, 3 p.m. to 9 p.m. Cultural Arts Center, 1097 Ocean Avenue, Sea Bright. (732) 229-5503.

SPRINGFIELD PUBLIC LIBRARY ''American Paintings'' by Brian J. Dursee. Through Sept. 2. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8:30 p.m.; Tuesdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Donald B. Palmer Museum, 66 Mountain Avenue, Springfield. (973) 376-4930.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''TAWA (Trenton Artists Workshop Association) Two Thousand.'' Through Sept. 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER ''Studio One.'' Through Aug. 31. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m. 18 Sterling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. No admission charge to the Gallery of American Craft. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.

JAMES YAROSH FINE ART AND DESIGN ''A Russian Fairy Tale: Fine Art of the Former Soviet Union.'' Through August. August's highlighted artist: Vachegan Narazyan. Hours: Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. 55 East Main Street, Holmdel. (732) 332-0056.

YOGI BERRA MUSEUM ''Baseball and Books,'' New Jersey Jackal players read baseball stories aloud to children before Wednesday night home games. Wednesday and Aug. 30 at 6 p.m. Artifacts from the life of the baseball player and exhibits on the history of the Yankees, baseball in New Jersey, Negro Leagues, evolution of equipment, and baseball during World War II. Ongoing. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Tickets: $4; $2 for children. Montclair State University, 8 Quarry Road, Little Falls. (973) 655-2377.
For Children
EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''Cowboy Vince.'' Saturday at 3 p.m. For ages 4 to 7. Tickets: $7.50. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.
MORRIS COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Reptile'' program. Today at 2 p.m. Free. Great Swamp Outdoor Education Center, 247 Southern Boulevard, Chatham Township. (973) 635-6629.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays at 2:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.

NEW JERSEY CHILDREN'S MUSEUM Daily programs: ''Fairy Tale Play'' at 10:30 a.m.; ''Storytime'' at noon; ''Special Craft Project'' at 2:30 p.m. Permanent exhibits: child-size grocery store, pizzeria and castle, prehistoric cave, computers and more. Tickets: $8. 599 Industrial Avenue, Paramus. (201) 262-5151.

SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Twice Is Nice'' crayon recycling program. Tomorrow, 9:30 a.m. to noon. Fee: $12. For children ages 3 and 4. Pre-registration is required. 190 Lord Stirling Road, Basking Ridge. (908) 766-2489.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER Planetarium Show. Today and next Sunday at 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. Fee: $3; $2.55 for older people. ''Nighttime Sweeties.'' Tuesday at 8 p.m. Fee: $4. ''Fairies' Dreams and Other Friends'' featuring Elaine Silver, folk singer. Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. Fee: $4. ''Sky Stories'' planetarium show. Thursday at 1:30 p.m. Fee: $3. Pre-registration is required. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.

WALT WHITMAN CULTURAL ARTS CENTER Fun Summer Fridays, through Aug. 25. The Big Tent Event, featuring the African-American Stilt Walker Ballet. Friday, 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Free; donations accepted. Wiggins Park, Camden waterfront. (856) 964-8300.
Spoken Word

BARNES & NOBLE Dr. Marie Miczak, pharmacologist, nutritional consultant and author, will discuss and sign his book ''How Not to Kill Yourself with Deadly Interactions.'' Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. Free. 3981 Highway 9, Freehold. (732) 409-2929.

BARNES & NOBLE Arthur Homme, Jr., author, will discuss and sign his book ''Midnight Frolic.'' Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Robert J. Danzig, author, will discuss and sign his book ''Angel Threads.'' Saturday, 2:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Free. 518 West Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston. (973) 535-9087.

LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES Joan Cohen, lecturer, will be the host of ''Puccini Opera Lecture.'' Wednesday at 8 p.m. ''Madame Butterfly'' will be presented. Tickets: $12. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.

MONTCLAIR PUBLIC LIBRARY Dr. Dorothy Zjawin, author, editor and teacher, will give a lecture and question and answer presentation entitled ''Tips on Getting Published,'' sponsored by the Write Group. Tuesday, 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. Free. 50 South Fullerton Street, Montclair. (973) 783-9131.
Etc.

ENGLEWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY ''Wednesday Night Comedy Film Festival.'' Through August. ''The Lavender Hill Mob.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Seating is limited to 65 people. 31 Engle Street, Englewood. (201) 568-2215, ext. 244.

GARDEN STATE EXHIBIT CENTER Antiques Weekend in Somerset. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; free for children under 16. Off Exit 10 of Route 287, 10 miles west of both the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway. (212) 255-0020.

HISTORIC COLD SPRING VILLAGE Saturday Evening Concert Series. Through Sept. 2. Ralph Roberts Band. Saturday at 6:30 p.m. Village Gazebo. Free. 720 Route 9, three miles north of Cape May City. (609) 898-2300.

MACCULLOCH HALL HISTORICAL MUSEUM ''Poetry in the Garden'' with Penelope Scambly Scott, poet, reading from ''Penelope: The Story of the Half-Scalped Woman.'' Today at 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $3 for students and older people; free for children under 12. Admission includes the Museum and exhibits. 45 Macculloch Avenue, Morristown. (973) 538-2404.
WHARTON's 25TH ANNUAL CANAL DAY FESTIVAL Country Fair and Craft Show. Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free. West Central Avenue, Wharton. (973) 366-1527.

WHEATON VILLAGE 20th Annual Antique Fire Apparatus Show and Muster. Today, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students; includes admission to all Wheaton Village attractions. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552.
